messageBody:
Being an advocate of self-documenting code, I don't like to litter my
code with JavaDocs either.

However, I do recognize their use in particular situations:
- Public APIs should be documented in full
- No harm in adding it at the top of a file (Class documentation), where
it does not really interfere with the rest of the class definition if it
would help understand the usage/purpose of a class
- Document unusually complex methods, assumptions, exceptions (as in
exception to the rule, not java.lang.Exception) / non supported
applications of the method/class...

I added this one, and then realized that it is more a guideline to be
followed when adding the documentation, not a reason to add
documentation per se:
- Stick to the what, not the how. Exception: you are documenting a
subclass (interface implementation) that provides a specific how.

Regards,

Manuel Amago.
